pullRequest.body:
A linter for "flexible" tactic.

The "flexible" linter makes sure that a "rigid" tactic (such as `rw`) does not act on the
output of a "flexible" tactic (such as `simp`).

This is an evolution of the "non-terminal `simp`" linter.

Zulip threads:
* [non-terminal `simp`](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/.60simp.60.20followers)
* [flexible vs rigid](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/flexible.20vs.20rigid.20tactics)

[Here is a gist](https://gist.github.com/adomani/2f7afc4bc515da47c3ff5c6e3f3bbbed) with the linter warnings from a previous run.

In #11822, the linter runs on most of mathlib and you can see in the output of CI what issues it flags.

---

This was also mentioned in passing in
[[Non-terminal simps in `Mathlib.Computability.PartrecCode`](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Non-terminal.20simps.20in.20.60Mathlib.2EComputability.2EPartrecCode.60)](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Non-terminal.20simps.20in.20.60Mathlib.2EComputability.2EPartrecCode.60)
and [`on_sides` tactic](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/.60on_sides.60.20tactic) for one possibility mentioned in a TODO above

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
I tend to agree this is a good idea. However, as discussed on Zulip, the number of false positives is still too high for us to enforce that idea as a linter that would run on every PR.

Is it possible to not make it part of the default linter suite? Then people can run it locally and fix the true positives they find.

Do you also have more recent output than what's in #11822?

### PR summary [3e30a03ba8](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11821/commits/3e30a03ba8a874bbf07e923a5840f4f1b2ac5b98)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic.Linter | 20 | 22 | +2 (+10.00%) |
| Mathlib.Tactic | 2174 | 2176 | +2 (+0.09%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 4140 files with changed transitive imports taking up over 174664 characters: this is too many to display!
You can run `scripts/import_trans_difference.sh all` locally to see the whole output.

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Stained`
`+ Stained.toFMVarId`
`+ extractCtxAndGoals`
`+ flexible`
`+ flexible?`
`+ flexibleLinter`
`+ getFVarIdCandidates`
`+ getStained`
`+ getStained!`
`+ goalsCreatedBy`
`+ goalsTargetedBy`
`+ instance : ToString Stained`
`+ persistFVars`
`+ reallyPersist`
`+ stoppers`
`+ toStained`
`+ usesGoal?`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

> Do you also have more recent output than what's in #11822?

I would still be interested in seeing more recent output

@grunweg could you please respond to the open conversations above? during a triage party, we felt that this was ready modulo the resolution of those conversations. We're assigning this to you for now as a result.
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by joneugster.

:v: adomani can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10728010030/job/29751620818)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10728010030/job/29751621375)

Thanks for jumping in reviewing, Jon and Anne. For me, finding the unobstructed time to review the whole linter proved rather difficult - I'm sorry for dropping the ball here, and very grateful you took up this task!

This is indeed very well documented! I have a few minor clarifications so the method of working is more understandable, but I'm happy to see this merged in approximately the current form.

bors d+
A first reading of the first 120 lines: mostly style comments.

I think it's reasonable that we make an effort to get this PR merged. @adomani could you address @grunweg 's comments, and quickly confirm that there is nothing in the Zulip threads which speaks against the linter?

Then I (or @grunweg ) can do another review and get this merged!

Michael and Jon, thank you very much for all your efforts and suggestions!

I should have addressed most comments and I fixed the tests as well.

I've finally took the time reading all of the code, it's really well documented!

I think the naming question above is not worth discussing any further (even though I agree that I didn't understand the names without doc-string either). Maybe @adomani can just call the decision and stick to whatever feels best.

I have a minor conceptual question (see below) but I'd suggest **delegation**:

maintainer merge

This is indeed very well documented! I have a few minor clarifications so the method of working is more understandable, but I'm happy to see this merged in approximately the current form.

bors d+
Michael, Jon and Anne, thank you so much for your reviews!  I accepted all of them.  I will try to find more informative names and will proceed to merge!  :octopus:

I went on a full revision of the documentation of the linter, in the hope of clarifying the ideas and the implementation.

The *code* did not change, but some names did.  I used `flexible`/`stoppers` instead of `followers`/`combinatorLike`, as well as the previously mentioned `goalsTargetedBy`/`goalsCreatedBy` instead of `activeGoalsBefore`/`activeGoalsAfter`.

I'll wait for CI to finish, leave it sitting for a few hours still and will merge unless I hear anything in between!

Thank you all again!

```suggestion
then you should replace `simp [...]` by one of

I believe the standard module docstring is this:
```suggestion
## Implementation notes

The current phrasing makes a jump from "syntax" taking inputs to "tactics. Is something like the following correct?
```suggestion
/-- `flexible? stx` is `true` if `stx` is syntax for a tactic that takes a "wide" variety of inputs and modifies
Would you like to record a follow-up TODO about considering other tactics? Or was this discussed on zulip already?
Added a TODO here.

```suggestion
This is mostly based on the heuristic that the tactic will "change" an `MVarId`.
Naming is hard: the current names sound to me like they describe *all* active goals before resp. after `t` (including the unchanged ones). I'm still thinking if I can think of better names...
I don't really have a better alternative: I was hoping that `active` would distinguish them from `all`...
`goalsResolvedBefore` or `goalsClosedBefore` maybe? (what's the correct term for eradicating a goal?)
I went for `goalsTargetedBy` and `goalsCreatedBy`, relating on the `TacticInfo` input to fill in `tactic`!
Do you think "created or changed" is clearer?
Added "created".
Can you remove this line in favour of writing `def extractCtxAndGoals  (take? : Syntax â†’ Bool) : InfoTree â†’` below?

I had it outside, since I wanted to highlight the fact that `take?` was "fixed" in the recursion.  I think that this would be useful if we want to add more heuristics to the tactic, but for the moment it could also be removed and simply do not add this flexibility.  Let me know what you prefer!

I think I've seen this in other places in mathlib when defining recursive functions. While I struggled to grasp the meaning the first time I've seen this pattern, I think this is just the idiomatic way of doing it.

So I'd suggest to leave it as is.
Sounds really nice and clear... but I only see one reference to it below, where `take` is always true. :thinking:
See previous comment: we can probably just replace `take?` by `true`.
I agree that this useful. Like `Array.filterMap` vs `Array.map`.

When I read this, i would have liked something like "(consider `simp only`)" but I'm not sure how to implement this since there are other flexible tactics beside `simp`

In any case, I suggest `â€¦` instead of `...`

I do not completely understand this comment: you would like the whole linter report to have something like a "title"?  Or should the linter suggest to squeeze the `simp`?

If the latter, I am not sure what to suggest: in fact, my biggest concern with this linter is that there are many cases in which the linter is correct in flagging an issue, but I do not know of a "good" way of avoiding the problem.
The latter, but Im well aware that I dont know of a good suggestion the linter could make either. That was merely a side-note!

Why are `ringNF` and `abelNF` stoppers (and not flexible tactics)? I thought something like

```lean
:= by
  ring_nf
  rw [h]
```

was valid syntax (but really bad style)

Looks like the intention is that they stop the spread of stain. So for example from the test, `simp; abel_nf; assumption` would be allowed because `abel_nf` puts everything in normal form. That's probably the best way to categorize them, but perhaps the comment above could be clearer about that.

Indeed, Anne's interpretation is what I was hoping to achieve.  Part of the confusion may be that this started being a "flag non-terminal `simp`" linter, before becoming "start by staining anything that `simp` touches until it is touched by a
* rigid tactic that would likely break with "small" changes in its input (and then complain);
* a stopper that produces some normal form and should have a stable output (and then stop staining further downstream code)"

linter.

I'll try to make the names and descriptions clearer though!
Ah I understand, thanks!
Please fix the `shake` warning :)
Done!

This docstring doesn't seem to match the actual implementation. Do I understand this correctly?
```suggestion
/-- `extractCtxAndGoals take? tree` takes as input a function `take? : Syntax â†’ Bool` and
an `InfoTree` and returns the array of pairs `(stx, mvars)`,
where `stx` is a syntax node such that `take? stx` is `true` and
`mvars` indicates the goal state:
 * the context before `stx`
 * the context after `stx`
 * a list of metavariables closed by `stx`
 * a list of metavariables created by `stx`

A typical usage is to find the goals following a `simp` application.
-/
```

To make the error searchable better, maybe include "flexible tactic" in the string?
```suggestion
    Linter.logLint linter.flexible stainStx m!"'{stainStx}' is a flexible tactic modifying '{d}'â€¦"
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: flexible linter and tests

source.title: test: make the flexible linter active by default
